Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Towards Context-Aware, Self-Organizing Wireless Small Cell Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Providing seamless, high quality wireless service anytime and anywhere requires substantial structural changes in today's macro-cellular networks. One such change, introducing small cell base stations, is seen as a highly promising solution. However, it requires meeting fundamental challenges: 1) nodes? self-organization, 2) network heterogeneity, and 3) high sensitivity of resource allocation to the system parameters. The proposed research addresses these challenges by exploring a dimension that has often been overlooked: the user's context. To achieve this goal, first, machine learning techniques are proposed to extract context from three dimensions: device, geo-location, and social metrics. Then, context-aware resource management schemes are developed by advancing novel techniques from matching theory - a powerful tool from economics and game theory. Subsequently, the learned context is leveraged to devise cooperative small cell models using new tools from coalitional game theory. Comprehensive evaluation is done via testbed implementation and software simulations.


The developed analytical tools will lay the foundations of context-aware, self-organizing small cell networks and will impact multiple disciplines such as communications, game theory, and social sciences. The generated results will provide fresh ideas for developing new small cell products. The research is fully integrated into the educational plan via incorporation in new and existing courses as well as training students via mentoring, participation in testbed development, and internships at industrial labs. A developed small cell educational tool will foster this integration via new hands-on activities and demonstrations to the community. Specialized outreach activities will contribute to increasing the participation of minority high school students in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project provided the scientific foundations needed to develop a new generation of wireless cellular networks that can directly factor in the context of its users. In particular, the intellectual merits included the development of novel algorithms at the intersection of game theory, machine learning, and communication theory, to improve the data rate, delay, and overall quality-of-experience that a wireless cellular network can offer. The developed algorithms played an important role in driving the research community towards developing the tenets of 5G cellular systems. Many of the concepts developed in this proposal, such as the idea of proactive caching and of machine learning-assisted wireless systems have now become critical topics and features of current and next-generation wireless systems. The developed resource management frameworks provides new insights on how a wireless system can properly manage its spectrum resources, with a focus on the optimization of multiple frequency bands, ranging from sub-6 GHz to millimeter wave (mmW) networks. The proposed research also led to new techniques, based on game theory and learning, that enable wireless devices to cooperate and enhance their quality-of-experience. The research on machine learning helped in identifying new context information, extracted from a user’s location, mobility, social network, device, and even physiological features, that can be used to enhance the performance of wireless services. The research results also paved the way towards integrating new services, such as virtual reality, over wireless cellular systems. The foundational nature of the research led to broad impacts across multiple disciplines ranging from wireless networks to game theory, machine learning, artificial intelligence, statistics, and network optimization. The broader impacts included a comprehensive educational plan that led to the creation of new courses at Virginia Tech and to a heavy involvement of undergraduate and graduate students in wireless research. One of the involved graduate students went on the pursue an academic career in the wireless networking area and several undergraduate students were exposed to first-hand research on wireless networking. A broad dissemination was done using tutorials, workshops, and special issues. The research also led to two major IEEE best paper awards.
